definition:
Weakly compact cardinals are (large) infinite cardinals which have a
property related to the syntactic compactness theorem for first order
logic. Specifically, for any infinite cardinal $\kappa$, consider the
language $L_{\kappa,\kappa}$.

This language is identical to first logic except that:

-   infinite conjunctions and disjunctions of fewer than $\kappa$
    formulas are allowed

-   infinite strings of fewer than $\kappa$ quantifiers are allowed

The weak compactness theorem for $L_{\kappa,\kappa}$ states that if
$\Delta$ is a set of sentences of $L_{\kappa,\kappa}$ such that
$|\Delta|=\kappa$ and any $\theta\subset\Delta$ with $|\theta|<\kappa$
is consistent then $\Delta$ is consistent.

A cardinal is weakly compact if the weak compactness theorem holds for
$L_{\kappa,\kappa}$.
